package is a set of content-based and domain-based macros
The macro names and their meanings are
listed below for quick reference; for
a detailed explanation on using the package, see
Note that this is not the usual macro package for Linux documentation,
although it is used for documentation of several widely used programs;
The macros are described in two groups, the first
includes the structural and physical page layout macros.
The second contains the manual and general text domain
To create a valid manual page, these three macros, in this order,
Section headers, paragraph breaks, lists and displays.
Valid headers, in the order of presentation:
Sections two and three function calls.
Normally used for section four device interface diagnostics.
Sections two and three error and signal
If a standard is not applicable, the history
of the subject should be given.
Customized headers may be added at
Indent and display one text line.
Indent and display one line of literal text.
Fl inset Ta "Inset or Run-on Labeled List"
MANUAL AND GENERAL TEXT DOMAIN MACROS
The manual and general text domain macros are special in that
most of them are parsed for callable macros
In this example, the option enclosure macro
is parsed, and calls the callable content macro
and then calls the callable content macro
Some macros may be callable, but are not parsed and vice versa.
These macros are indicated in the
Unless stated, manual domain macros share a common syntax:
punctuation characters are recognized as such only if they are presented
is not recognized as punctuation and will be output with a leading white
space and in what ever font the calling macro uses.
is recognized as three sequential closing punctuation characters
and a leading white space is not output between the characters
The special meaning of a punctuation character may be escaped
Ad Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Address. (This macro may be deprecated.)"
An Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Author name."
Ar Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Command-line argument."
Cm Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Command-line argument modifier."
Dv Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Defined variable (source code)."
Er Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Error number (source code)."
Ev Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Environment variable."
Fa Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Function argument."
Fd Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Function declaration."
Fn Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Function call (also .Fo and .Fc)."
Ic Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Interactive command."
Li Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Literal text."
Nm Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Command name."
Op Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Option (also .Oo and .Oc)."
Ot Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Old style function type (Fortran only)."
Pa Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Pathname or filename."
St Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Standards (
Va Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Variable name."
Vt Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Variable type (Fortran only)."
Xr Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Manual Page Cross Reference."
%B Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Reference book title."
%J Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Reference journal title."
%T Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Reference article title."
Ac Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Angle close quote."
Ao Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Angle open quote."
Ap Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Apostrophe."
Aq Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Angle quote."
Bc Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Bracket close quote."
Bo Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Bracket open quote."
Bq Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Bracket quote."
Bx Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta Bx .
Dc Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Double close quote."
Do Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Double open quote."
Dq Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Double quote."
Ec Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Enclose string close quote."
Em Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Emphasis (traditional English)."
Eo Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Enclose string open quote."
No Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Normal text (no-op)."
Ns Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "No space."
Pc Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Parenthesis close quote."
Po Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Parenthesis open quote."
Pq Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Parentheses quote."
Qc Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Straight Double close quote."
Ql Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Quoted literal."
Qo Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Straight Double open quote."
Qq Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Straight Double quote."
No Ta "Return values (sections two and three only)."
Sc Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Single close quote."
So Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Single open quote."
Sq Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Single quote."
Sx Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Section Cross Reference."
Sy Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta "Symbolic (traditional English)."

Ux Ta Yes Ta Yes Ta Ux

.\" .It Sy \&Hf Ta \&No Ta \&No Ta "Include file with header"
quote remaining items on the argument list.
begin a quote which may span more than one line of input and
are close quoted with the matching macro name ending in
Enclosure macros may be nested and are limited to
Note: the extended argument list macros
The extended list macros are used when the number of macro arguments
The macros UR (starting a URI/URL hypertext reference), UE (ending one),
and UN (identifying a target for a reference) are also available.
for more information on these macros.
